title: What if provision isn't about having enough, but sharing what you have?
teaser: Your pantry is full but you're still afraid. 47.9M food insecure while others stockpile. The scarcity mindset is killing us.
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE PANTRY IS FULL BUT YOU'RE STILL AFRAID
panels.content:
You have three months of rice in storage. Canned goods stacked to the ceiling. Emergency supplies hidden in the basement.

But you're still scrolling through prepper forums at midnight. Still calculating how long your stockpile will last. Still afraid it won't be enough.

47.9 million Americans are food insecure. But that's not you. You have plenty.

So why do you feel like you're starving?

Because the scarcity mindset isn't about what you have. It's about the belief that there will never be enough.

And that belief makes you hoard what you'll never use while others go without what they desperately need.

panels.heading: THE ANXIETY ECONOMY
panels.content:
The economy is teaching you to be afraid.

Inflation. Recession fears. Supply chain disruptions. Price gouging. Every headline screams: **Get yours before it's gone.**

So you stockpile. You buy in bulk. You prepare for the worst. You hold tight to what you have because releasing it feels like suicide.

Your ancestors survived by sharing. Your grandparents lived through the Depression by pooling resources. Your great-grandparents knew mutual aid.

But you? You've been trained to compete for scraps.

The anxiety economy wins when you believe scarcity is inevitable.

And you prove it true by hoarding what could save someone else.

panels.heading: THE COST OF NEVER ENOUGH
panels.content:
The cost of the scarcity mindset is this: **You have everything and experience nothing.**

Your savings account grows but you can't enjoy it. Your pantry overflows but you panic at the thought of using it. You have resources but live like you're broke.

Because if there's never enough, then having more changes nothing.

The bar just moves. The goalpost shifts. The number that would make you feel secure keeps climbing.

$10,000 becomes $50,000. $50,000 becomes $100,000. $100,000 becomes a million.

And you're still afraid.

Because scarcity isn't an economic problem. It's a spiritual crisis.

You're trying to solve a trust issue with a bank account.

illustration.description: Dithered image of overflowing pantry with anxious figure, or graph with moving goalpost

panels.heading: THE ANCIENT PATTERN
panels.content:
There's an ancient story about this.

3,500 years ago, enslaved people were freed from Egypt. They walked into the wilderness with nothing. No infrastructure. No supply chain. No reserves.

And they panicked.

So God provided—bread from the sky every morning. Enough for the day. Fresh every 24 hours.

But the people didn't trust it. They hoarded. They stockpiled tomorrow's portion today.

And it rotted.

Because the provision wasn't designed to be accumulated. It was designed to be **received daily and shared freely.**

The question then—and now—is the same:

**What if provision isn't about having enough, but trusting the One who provides?**

panels.heading: THE INVITATION TO TRUST
panels.content:
You're being invited into a different economy.

Not one where you hoard to survive. But one where you trust enough to share.

Not one where scarcity is the baseline. But one where abundance flows through open hands.

The world tells you: **Accumulate. Protect. Never let go.**

But there's an older voice, a deeper wisdom that says:

**"Give us this day our daily bread."**

Not this year's supply. Not next decade's security. Today's bread.

Because provision isn't about stockpiling for every possible future.

It's about trusting that you'll have what you need when you need it.

And maybe—just maybe—having enough to share.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

My pantry is full but I'm still afraid. I have more than I need but it never feels like enough.

I've been taught to hoard, to protect, to accumulate until I feel safe.

But the goalpost keeps moving. The number keeps climbing. And I'm exhausted.

You say provision isn't about stockpiling. It's about trust.

I don't know how to do that. I don't know how to open my hands when the world says clench your fists.

Teach me.

What if provision isn't about having enough, but sharing what I have?

Show me what that looks like.

Amen.
